stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on a Wild West-themed level, showcasing off-stream progress on the level layout and a treasure hunt mission. The main on-stream activities were creating a cowboy Shy Guy NPC from scratch, including modeling and texturing, and beginning the process of ripping and redesigning the Monty Mole model from the original SM64. The stream also featured collaboration with Biobak on pipe models and integration of assets made by Zeina.

development_findings.summary: The current level being developed is a Wild West-themed world, temporarily named 'Grandstand Badlands'.

The level will feature multiple boss fights themed around catching outlaws, including a shootout with five Goombas at a train station, a fight with a Snifit in a secret mine, and a boss fight against a Monty Mole after a bank robbery.
development_findings.quote: This town ain't big enough for the six of us.

development_findings.summary: The team cannot currently use the F3DEX3 microcode because it causes a 20% performance drop compared to their current solution.
development_findings.quote: I imported F3DEX3 and it decreased FPS by 20%.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is refactoring older assets, like the Shy Guy model, to use the game's world lighting system for better visual consistency.
Kaze struggled to create a vest texture for the cowboy Shy Guy, highlighting a gap in his skillset and his willingness to improvise solutions.
development_findings.quote: I usually don't paint texture so I don't really know how it works. I'm kind of just improvising here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is ripping and completely remaking the Monty Mole from the original Super Mario 64, as its original animations and bone structure are unusable.
Kaze is uncertain about some of the level's props, such as a giant gun, feeling they might be too serious or out of place for the desired surreal vibe.
development_findings.quote: I think the big-ass gun looks too serious... I wanted this one to feel a little more surreal I guess but I'm not really a hundred percent on the idea.

development_findings.summary: The team is considering what NPCs to include in the town to make it feel cohesive, listing Yoshis, Toads, Monty Moles, Shy Guys, Snuffits, and Goombas.
The game maintains a family-friendly tone; the Wild West level will feature characters drinking milk at a milk bar and using cork guns.
development_findings.quote: We have to keep this like pg-8, you know. They're all gonna be drinking milk. They're gonna shoot cork guns.

context_findings.summary: Kaze claims he never experiences burnout, attributing it humorously to not having a soul and being like a robot who just makes games.
context_findings.quote: No, I actually never suffer from burnout. And that's because I do not have a soul.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy for this game is to tell stories through the levels, rather than just creating collections of stars like in a previous hack.
context_findings.quote: I want to tell stories in this game.

context_findings.summary: Despite his focus on optimization, Kaze values fun gameplay over pure technical achievement when playing games.
context_findings.quote: I don't care if a game is a technical achievement I just want to play fun games. I'm like the last person that should say this but it is the truth.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is reconsidering the game's main plot, feeling the original 'Yoshi slave labor' concept might be too dark. He notes that plot is secondary and will be finalized later to fit the completed levels.
context_findings.quote: The whole Yoshi slave labor plot is maybe a bit too dark maybe it's more like just Bowser kidnaps the Yoshi... plot in Mario games is kind of very secondary.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has recently changed his philosophy on optimization, realizing that polygon count is less important than he previously thought, allowing him to create more detailed models.
context_findings.quote: Triangle count is completely overrated. In fact, it's so overrated I have a whole video about how overrated it is... That's why he was so low poly at the beginning. But now that I know, we can just add more, I guess.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's biggest pet peeve in video games is digital movement controls, especially when analog sticks are forced to emulate a D-pad, which he considers inexcusable in modern games.
context_findings.quote: I remember playing Spyro on ps1 and Instantly I was like dude this game is shit and I realized it was because of the d-pad... they put an emulated d-pad on the stick Instead of giving you proper analog controls. I was so pissed.

context_findings.summary: To immerse himself in the Wild West theme for the current level, Kaze has been watching many cowboy movies, describing his design process as a form of 'method acting'.
context_findings.quote: The last two weeks have actually been crazy. I've been watching so many cowboy movies I've been I'm basically method acting designing a video game.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided feedback on Kaze's new pipe models, suggesting they should not be smooth shaded.
biobak.quote: They're cool, but they shouldn't be smooth shaded.

biobak.summary: Biobak sent Kaze an edited, shinier version of the pipe model for review.
Kaze analyzed Biobak's pipe model edit and determined it was achieved by turning off lighting, which he explained was not a viable solution as it breaks environment maps and world integration.
biobak.quote: Oh, that's how you made the top shiny I see... Okay, you can't have lighting off it doesn't work by a leg if you have lighting off your environment map doesn't work.

biobak.summary: Biobak was creating a new cowboy hat model for Yoshi.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the dragon model for a treasure hunt area.
Zeina manually created the rock and dead tree models for the train station area.
Kaze found and removed some unnecessary internal polygons ('sneaky triangles') from Zeina's rock models.
zeina.quote: Well, you put in a triangles to the inside of these which would be sneaky triangles But they are very easy to just pick and delete.

zeina.summary: Zeina was working on a cowboy Goomba model during the stream.
Kaze praised a cowboy Koopa model Zeina was working on, calling it 'Se√±or Koopa'.
zeina.quote: Okay, zayna this is looking very fun I like him senor koopa He looks so much like a cowboy wow.

key_stories.title: Creating the Cowboy Shy Guy
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to create a cowboy Shy Guy for the new level. The process involved refactoring an old model, improvising a vest after struggling with texture painting, and adding a hat and holster to complete the look. This story showcases his iterative design process and how he overcomes skill gaps.
key_stories.challenge: A themed NPC was needed for the new Wild West level.
key_stories.process: Kaze started with an old Shy Guy model, refactored its lighting, and added a cowboy hat. He struggled to paint a convincing vest texture, eventually settling on a polygonal cutout solution. He replaced the idea of a held gun with a simpler holster and tweaked the model's proportions based on his own judgment and chat feedback.
key_stories.outcome: After several iterations and improvisations, a functional cowboy Shy Guy model with a hat, vest, and holster was created and placed in the level, ready for programming.
key_stories.key_quote: I usually don't paint texture so I don't really know how it works. I'm kind of just improvising here.

key_stories.title: Designing 'Grandstand Badlands'
key_stories.summary: Kaze detailed his design process for the Wild West level, focusing on making it thematic and purposeful. He outlined a structure with multiple unique areas and a series of interconnected 'outlaw' boss fights, while also contemplating larger narrative decisions to ensure the right tone.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed to define the structure and content for the Wild West level to ensure it was thematic and engaging.
key_stories.process: Kaze designed the level with a town, a surreal wilderness, and a train station. He planned three of the main stars to be boss fights against different outlaws (Goombas, a Snifit, a Monty Mole). He also debated the overall tone, considering toning down a darker 'Yoshi slave labor' plotline to better fit the game.
key_stories.outcome: A clear plan for the level was established, including three distinct zones and multiple interconnected boss fights centered on an 'outlaw' theme, giving the level a strong narrative purpose.
key_stories.key_quote: This level is like the first one that has those applied and I'm pretty happy with it. It's very thematic everything is purposeful and I like that a lot.

key_stories.title: Pipe Model Collaboration
key_stories.summary: A collaborative effort to improve the game's pipes revealed the technical constraints of the N64 engine. Biobak proposed an aesthetic change, and Kaze's analysis of the implementation revealed it would break the game's lighting system, showcasing the back-and-forth between artistic vision and technical reality.
key_stories.challenge: The team was iterating on a core game asset, the warp pipes, to improve their visual quality.
key_stories.process: Kaze created new pipe models. Biobak provided feedback that they shouldn't be smooth shaded and sent back an edited version with a more intense shine. Kaze analyzed Biobak's file, deduced that the effect was achieved by disabling the lighting, and explained why this was technically incompatible with the game's rendering engine.
key_stories.outcome: The collaboration resulted in a deeper technical understanding of the asset's requirements, even if the proposed change wasn't immediately viable. It highlights the necessary technical dialogue between art and programming.
key_stories.key_quote: Okay, you can't have lighting off it doesn't work by a leg if you have lighting off your environment map doesn't work and If you have lighting off the pipe doesn't look proper in the world, so we need to keep lighting on.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned the original plot for the game involved 'Yoshi slave labor' but he is now considering changing it because it 'is maybe a bit too dark'.
questions: What was the original, full story concept for the game?
What specifically made you reconsider the 'slave labor' plot point?
How do you and the team balance creating a story with stakes against the generally lighthearted tone of a Mario game?
How will the final plot be decided, and who on the team has input on it?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that using the F3DEX3 microcode results in a 20% performance drop, making it unusable for the project at the moment.
questions: Can you elaborate on the technical reasons for this performance drop?
What are the primary benefits of F3DEX3 that made you want to use it in the first place?
Is there a plan to revisit this, or are you committed to the current microcode for the entire project?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that a contributor named Silas had a 'cool idea' to rework the game's 'squishiness function'.
questions: Who is Silas and what is his role on the project?
What is the 'squishiness function' and what problem were you trying to solve with it?
What was the 'cool idea' Silas proposed?

open_questions.context: Zeina and Kaze, who are married, collaborate closely on the game's assets, with Kaze providing direct technical feedback on her models during the stream.
questions: Can you walk me through your typical creative workflow, from concept to final asset in the game?
How do you navigate creative disagreements or feedback when you are both partners in life and on this project?
Zeina, how much influence do you have on the broader artistic direction or level themes beyond the specific assets you create?

open_questions.context: Kaze described the Wild West level as having three distinct boss fights against different outlaw groups: Snifits, Goombas, and a Monty Mole.
questions: What was the inspiration for making a level with three separate boss fights, which is unusual for the game?
How are you designing these encounters to feel distinct from one another?
Can you describe the gameplay mechanics of the 'shootout' with the Goombas and their cork guns?
